title.narrative: Consolider le Canadian Development Economics Study Group
Strengthening the Canadian Development Economics Study Group

description.narrative: Canada has a vibrant, yet small, community of development economists at universities across the country. Over time, their research interests and their network of developing-country economists have expanded. This project will provide funding to build on this foundation by promoting academic excellence and policy discussions through the Canadian Development Economics Study Group (CDESG). Advancing development economics CDESG was created in 2005 to support the Canadian Economics Association's (CEA) annual conference programming on development issues. IDRC has provided funding since 2007 for CDESG to -organize policy panels on development economics -sponsor developing country scholars to present their work at the conference -build a website to connect researchers in Canada and abroad -establish an annual Albert Berry Prize for the best conference paper in development economics by a junior scholar CDESG also strives to encourage research uptake by policymakers in Canada by organizing policy panels and discussions in Ottawa. Building on progress This project will allow CDESG to continue its valuable work. Specifically, the funds will support -keynote speakers and policy panels at the CEA annual conferences -conference participation for development economists from developing countries -the Albert Berry prize -pre-CEA conference CDESG days CDESG will also hold special workshops in Ottawa for discussions with development policymakers and those who use development economics research. This will allow participants to identify research priorities based on policy needs. Other activities will include collaborative frameworks with several organizations in Canada and abroad, improvements to the CDESG website, and projects to engage CDESG members in disseminating their research more pro-actively.
